  "article_text": [
    "a harmonic function on @xmath0 is a distribution solution to the laplace equation @xmath1 which is necessarily a smooth function . a classical theorem of gauss and koebe states that a continuous function on @xmath0 is harmonic if and only if it satisfies the mean value property with respect to the sphere @xmath2 .",
    "on the other hand the laplacian @xmath3 admits an invariant - theoretic interpretation relative to the orthogonal group @xmath4 .",
    "namely the @xmath5-algebra of @xmath4-invariant polynomials in @xmath6 is generated by the squared distance function @xmath7 and the laplacian @xmath8 is the result of substituting @xmath9 into @xmath10 .",
    "these two characterizations of harmonic functions allow us to generalize the notion in two directions , that is , to polyhedral harmonics and to group harmonics .",
    "let @xmath11 be an @xmath12-dimensional polytope in @xmath13 and @xmath14 the @xmath15-dimensional skeleton of @xmath11 , that is , the union of all @xmath15-dimensional faces of @xmath11 .",
    "a continuous function @xmath16 on @xmath0 is said to be @xmath14-_harmonic _ if it satisfies the mean value property with respect to @xmath14 , that is , if @xmath17 where @xmath18 is the @xmath15-dimensional euclidean measure on @xmath14 with @xmath19 being its total volume .",
    "let @xmath20 denote the set of all @xmath14-harmonic functions on @xmath0 . a general result of iwasaki ( * ?",
    "* theorem 1.1 ) states that @xmath20 is a finite - dimensional linear space of polynomials .",
    "it is naturally an @xmath21$]-module , that is , stable under partial differentiations . if @xmath22 is the symmetry group of @xmath14 , then it is also an @xmath23$]-module , that is , stable under the natural action of @xmath22 .",
    "moreover , if @xmath14 enjoys ample symmetry , that is , if @xmath22 acts on @xmath0 irreducibly then @xmath20 is a finite - dimensional linear space of harmonic polynomials ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.4 ) .",
    "let @xmath24 be a subgroup of @xmath4 and @xmath25^g$ ] the @xmath5-algebra of @xmath24-invariant polynomials of @xmath26 .",
    "a @xmath24-_harmonic _ function on @xmath0 is a distribution solution to the system of pdes : @xmath27^g_+),\\ ] ] where @xmath25^g_+$ ] is the maximal ideal of @xmath25^g$ ] consisting of those @xmath10 s without constant term : @xmath28 ( see helgason ( * ? ? ? * chap .",
    "iii ) ) . let @xmath29 denote the set of all @xmath24-harmonic functions on @xmath0 .",
    "to define system , the polynomial @xmath10 may not range over all @xmath25^g_+$ ] , but only over a set of generators of @xmath25^g_+$ ] .",
    "for example , if @xmath24 is the entire @xmath4 then @xmath25^{o(n)}_+$ ] is generated by the squared distance function only , so that system reduces to the single laplace equation . in this article",
    ", @xmath24 will be a finite group in general and a finite reflection group in particular .",
    "steinberg @xcite shows that if @xmath24 is a finite group then @xmath29 is a finite - dimensional linear space of polynomials with @xmath30 , the order of @xmath24 .",
    "when @xmath24 is a finite reflection group , he goes on to determine @xmath29 explicitly .",
    "namely , as an @xmath21$]-module @xmath29 is generated by the fundamental alternating polynomial @xmath31 of @xmath24 , and as an @xmath32$]-module it is the regular representation of @xmath24 , in particular @xmath33 .",
    "when @xmath34 is the symmetry group of @xmath14 , it makes sense to compare @xmath20 with @xmath35 . according to a result in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* formula ( 2.14 ) ) there is always the inclusion @xmath36 it is known that @xmath20 coincides with @xmath35 when @xmath11 is any regular convex polytope with center at the origin , in which case @xmath22 is an irreducible finite reflection group so that @xmath37 is determined by steinberg s theorem ; see iwasaki ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 4.4 ) and the references therein .",
    "one can show that the coincidence also occurs , for example , for the truncated icosahedron @xmath38 $ ] of an archimedean solid , or the soccer ball .",
    "so far , however , no polytope with ample symmetry has been known for which inclusion is strict ( for some @xmath39 ) , that is , polyhedral harmonics is strictly larger than group harmonics .",
    "the aim of this article is to present the first examples of such polytopes .",
    "they arise from a one - parameter family of isohedral triakis tetrahedra as well as from a one - parameter family of isohedral triakis octahedra in three dimensions .",
    "the former family contains a desired example for @xmath40 , but none for @xmath41 ( see theorem [ thm : main - tetra ] ) , while the latter family contains such an example for every @xmath42 ( see theorem [ thm : main - octa ] ) . in this respect",
    "the latter family is more interesting than the former , but in any case we begin with the simpler case of the former family and then proceed to the latter .",
    "0.1 in    ( 29.0000 , 26.8000 ) ( 3.9000,-28.5000 )    ( 17.5000,-3.4000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath43(23.6000,-30.2000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath44(32.9000,-22.9000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath45(3.9000,-22.7000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath46    ( 16.0000,-19.9000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath47(32.7000,-10.7000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath48(22.7000,-14.4000)(0,0)[lb]@xmath49    an _ isohedral triakis tetrahedron _ is obtained from a regular tetrahedron by adjoining to each face of it a pyramid ( based on that face ) of appropriate height , or excavating such a pyramid , where a polyhedron is said to be _ isohedral _ if its symmetry group is transitive on its faces , that is , if all faces are equivalent under symmetries of the polyhedron ; see grnbaum and shephard @xcite .",
    "our triakis tetrahedron @xmath11 depends on a positive parameter @xmath50 . to describe it more neatly ,",
    "let @xmath51 be the regular tetrahedron with which we get started ; it is centered at the origin @xmath47 and with four vertices @xmath43 , @xmath44 , @xmath45 , @xmath46 .",
    "if @xmath49 denotes the center of the face @xmath52 , then the pyramid based on this face has the top vertex @xmath48 that lies on the ray emanating from @xmath47 and passing through @xmath49 in such a manner that the distance ratio @xmath53 is @xmath54 ( see figure [ fig : triakis - tetra ] ) .",
    "the polyhedron @xmath11 has four six - valent vertices @xmath43 , @xmath44 , @xmath45 , @xmath46 and four three - valent vertices @xmath55 , @xmath56 , @xmath57 , @xmath48 , where @xmath55 , @xmath56 , @xmath57 are defined in a similar manner as the vertex @xmath48 is , and @xmath11 has twelve faces and eighteen edges .",

    ", width=226,height=226 ]    @xmath60    the values @xmath61 and @xmath59 are special in that as a point set , @xmath11 degenerates to the tetrahedron @xmath51 at @xmath61 and it becomes a cube @xmath62 at @xmath59 . for @xmath63 , @xmath11",
    "is obtained from @xmath51 by adjoining a pyramid to each face of @xmath51 , while for @xmath60 , it is obtained by excavating such a pyramid .",
    "moreover @xmath11 is convex if and only if @xmath64 , in which interval the value @xmath65 is distinguished in that @xmath11 becomes a catalan solid @xcite , or an archimedean dual solid , whose dual is the truncated tetrahedron @xmath66 $ ] .",
    "when @xmath61 , although the four points @xmath43 , @xmath44 , @xmath45 , @xmath48 are coplanar , we think of @xmath67 , @xmath68 , @xmath69 as distinct faces of @xmath11 , and thus @xmath70 , @xmath71 , @xmath72 as edges , and @xmath48 as a vertex of @xmath11 .",
    "similarly , when @xmath59 , although the four points @xmath43 , @xmath44 , @xmath57 , @xmath48 are coplanar , we think of @xmath73 and @xmath67 as distinct faces of @xmath11 , and thus @xmath74 as an edge of @xmath11 . with this convention , as a combinatorial polyhedron , @xmath11 has the constant skeletal structure for all @xmath75 .",
    "let @xmath22 be the symmetry group of @xmath14 .",
    "when @xmath40 , for every @xmath75 the group @xmath22 is always the same as the symmetry group of the tetrahedron @xmath51 , which we denote by @xmath76 since it is a weyl group of type @xmath77 . on the other hand , when @xmath41 , the group @xmath22 stays the same as @xmath76 as long as @xmath78 , but at @xmath59 it jumps up to be the symmetry group of the cube @xmath62 , which is denoted by @xmath79 as being a weyl group of type @xmath80 . for simplicity of notation ,",

    "note that @xmath85    it is our problem to consider how @xmath20 behaves as @xmath50 varies and when @xmath20 is strictly larger than @xmath35 .",
    "any value of @xmath50 with this phenomenon is referred to as a _",
    "critical value_. it turns out that the vertex @xmath86 and face @xmath87 problems have no critical values , but the edge @xmath88 problem certainly has a critical value @xmath89 .",
    "it is an algebraic integer of degree six that is the unique positive root of a sextic equation @xmath90 how this algebraic equations arises will be explained in  [ subsec : edge - tetra ] .",
    "the volume problem @xmath91 need not be dealt with independently , since the isohedrality of @xmath11 implies @xmath92 by a result of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.2 ) so that the face and volume problems have the same solution .",

    "this proves the second assertion of the lemma . @xmath193",

    "let @xmath269 be a regular octahedron with center at the origin @xmath47 .",
    "the six vertices of @xmath269 can be written @xmath270 , @xmath271 , @xmath272 , where @xmath273 and @xmath274 are antipodal to each other and so on .",

    "an _ isohedral triakis octahedron _",
    "@xmath11 is obtained from @xmath269 by adjoining to each face of it a pyramid of appropriate height , or excavating such a pyramid , just as in the construction of an isohedral triakis tetrahedron .",
    "let @xmath277 denote the top vertex of the pyramid based on the face @xmath275 .",

    "neighboring faces , say , @xmath287 and @xmath288 are coplanar .",
    "note that @xmath11 is convex if and only if @xmath289 , in which interval the value @xmath290 is distinguished in that @xmath11 becomes a catalan solid @xcite , or an archimedean dual solid , called the small triakis octahedron , whose dual is the truncated cube @xmath291 $ ] .",

    "indeed the treatment of triakis octahedra will be very parallel to that of triakis tetrahedra , so that the main focus in what follows will be on how one can modify the arguments in the tetrahedral case to the octahedral one .",
    "we consider how lemma [ lem : pde - tetra ] can be modified .",

    "it is an interesting exercise left behind to deal with a similar problem for isohedral triakis icosahedra",
    ". it would also be interesting if such special solids as discussed in this article appear in nature and physical sciences .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we describe the harmonic functions for certain isohedral triakis solids . </S>",
    "<S> they are the first examples for which polyhedral harmonics is strictly larger than group harmonics . </S>",
    "<S> + keywords : polyhedral harmonics ; group harmonics ; isohedral triakis tetrahedron ; isohedral triakis octahedron ; finite reflection groups ; invariant differential equations . </S>"
  ]
}
